itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
Welcome to the Practice Sample Test
Let's try some question types with an explanation on how to answer them...

This short test, will help you to learn how to answer the different types of question that you will face in the Chemistry test ...
Centered on the bottom, the "Submit" button enables you to submit your answers.
On the right handside, a scrolling cursor enables you to navigate along the test, to access the question individually.
Also centered on the top, a timer will be displayed, with the time left to the end of the test!
After proceeding at the end of the test, you will see your scoring. You can then exit while clicking on the button "HOME", or review your answer with the marking. The feedback, if any available, is displayed in green at the bottom of a question.

Good luck !

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: Click on "Sardinia" country on the map below, the original CD-Rom EChemTest cover map ...

This is a "Hot-Spot" graphic question. Move the mouse pointer onto the map spot representing the appropriate country place, then click: the red point will move to the point where you clicked; you can change your mind, by just clicking on another spot.
Yes correct, this is Sardinia, an island belonging to Italia.
Wrong answer, getting back to your geographical book ...

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: Select within the list, the correct statement that described the best the salt compound?

This is a Multiple choice question, with only one choice to be selected. Click on the item below that seems correct to you. If you change your mind , just click on an another answer, it will autoatically unselect the previous tick. Typical symbol is a circle (unique choice). Once you are sure of your answer, validate your answer by clicking on the appropriate button.
Salt is a white cubic crystalline compound.
Salt is a dark red cristal.
Salt has no ionic bonds and is as hard as diamond.
Salt is a white compound that is impossible to dissolve in water.
Right, the crystaline structure is cubic, the color is white.
The common color is white, or kind of yellow-brownish, but not red at all (Ruby).
Salt is a pure ionic compound, composed of sodium Na+ cations and chlorine Cl- anions, that makes salt easily breakable.
Yes salt has a white color, but it is certainly one of the most soluble in water, up to 330g/L at room temperature.
Salt: white color, soluble in water, and pure ionic cubic cristal that makes salt easily breakable.

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: Select the list of country states that composed the first "European" organization ?

This is a Multiple choice question, with only one choice to be selected. Click on the item below that seems correct to you. If you change your mind , just click on an another answer, it will autoatically unselect the previous tick. Typical symbol is a circle (unique choice). Once you are sure of your answer, validate your answer by clicking on the appropriate button.
Belgium, France, Germany, Italia, Luxemburg, Netherland<BR \>
Belgium, Denmark, Germany, Italy, Luxemburg, Netherland<BR \>
Belgium, Germany, France, Italy, Netherland<BR \>
Benelux, Germany, France, Italy, Ireland<BR \>

Right, the correct statement is :
Belgium, Deutschland, France, Italia, Luxembourg, Nederland
The first "European organization" was composed by 6 members. Denmark and Ireland joigned the organization much later.
The first "European organization" was composed by 6 members. Denmark and Ireland joigned the organization much later.
The first "European organization" was composed by 6 members. Denmark and Ireland joigned the organization much later.

... but the correct statement is :Belgium, Deutschland, France, Italia, Luxembourg, Nederland<BR \>The first "European organization" was composed by 6 members. Denmark and Ireland joigned the organization much later.

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
When does Niels Bohr proposed his quantic model of atom?
Type in the box below the 4 digits of the year (e.g. 2013)
This is a Numerical question. You are supposed to click on the box below with the mouse, and to type in the digits number.
Yes, this is the correct answer. The quantic model of atom was proposed in 1913, we are celebrating the 100th anniversary in 2013.
Well the correct answer is 1913, already 100 years ago (in 2013).

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
When was the first European Organization first created?
Type in the box below the 4 digits of the year (e.g. 1999)
This is a Numerical question. You are supposed to click on the box below with the mouse, and to type in the digits number.
Yes, this is the correct answer.<BR \>The European organization was born in 1956, and was composed by the 6 following country states (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands)

Not too bad ... almost good !!
The European organization was born in 1956, and was composed by the 6 following country states (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands)

Sorry, this is not the correct answer ; it was a few years after !
The European organization was born in 1956, and was composed by the 6 following country states (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands)

Sorry, this is not the correct answer ; it was before !
The European organization was born in 1956, and was composed by the 6 following country states (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands)
Well the correct answer is 1956.<BR \>The European organization was born in 1956, and was composed by the 6 following country states (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands)

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
Considering the following formula modelizing the filtration profile:

Porosity d = 4·K·A / p    Flow D = N·Δp·r2 / 8·η·L

Select and tick which of the parameters listed below, can have a negative effect on filtration if increased?

This is a Multiple response question. You are supposed to select the correct statements (one or more, 3 in that case). There may be a limitation in the number of items you can select. For example, here you are not supposed to click on more than 3 items. If you want to change your mind, de-select the item you don't want anymore by re-clicking on it, and then select the new item chosen.
A: liquid superficial tension at 20°C
d: porosity
K: constant
Δp: difference of pressure in / out
p: gaz pressure
D: flow in mL/min
N: number of canicula "surface"
r: average canicula radius
η: liquid viscocity
L: canicula length "thickness"

respcondition.title: 3 Dp: difference of pressure in / out

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 Dp: difference of pressure in / out

itemfeedback.ident: 3 Dp: difference of pressure in / out

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
Considering the following formula modelizing the filtration profile:

Porosity d = 4·K·A / p    Flow D = N·Δp·r2 / 8·η·L

Select and tick which of the parameters listed below, can have a positive effect on filtration if increased?

This is a Multiple response question. You are supposed to select the correct statements (one or more, 3 in that case). There may be a limitation in the number of items you can select. For example, here you are not supposed to click on more than 3 items. If you want to change your mind, de-select the item you don't want anymore by re-clicking on it, and then select the new item chosen.
A: liquid superficial tension at 20°C
d: porosity
K: constant
Δp: difference of pressure in / out
p: gaz pressure
D: flow in mL/min
N: number of canicula "surface"
r: average canicula radius
η: liquid viscocity
L: canicula length "thickness"

respcondition.title: 3 Dp: difference of pressure in / out

displayfeedback.linkrefid: 3 Dp: difference of pressure in / out

itemfeedback.ident: 3 Dp: difference of pressure in / out

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
Text option 1: "Select from the list below, the correct items:" (no indication of the number of correct items)
or
Text option 2: "Select from the list below, the 3 correct items:" (indication of the number of correct items)

This is a Multiple response question. You are supposed to select the correct statements (one or more, 3 in that case). There may be a limitation in the number of items you can select. For example, here you are not supposed to click on more than 3 items. If you want to change your mind, de-select the item you don't want anymore by re-clicking on it, and then select the new item chosen.
In 2013, Norway is a member of the European Union.
Europe, European Union, European Economical Area, are all having the same meaning.
Switzerland is member of the European Economical Area.
The Scandic area is including Norway, Sweden and Finland.
The Baltic area is including Estonia, Latvia, Poland and Lithuania.
Iberic area is including only 2 EU member states.
Yes correct !
You can not select all items. Wrong strategy !
No, Norway is member of the European Economical Area and not member of the European Union; nevertheless Norway is in Europe.
No, not having the same meaning: the European Economical Area is larger than the European Union; Geographical Europe is going up to the Ural Mountain ranges.
Yes correct, as is Norway for example.
Yes right, Denmark is also part of the Scandic area.
No Poland is not part of the Baltic area, even if Lithuania and Poland have of common border.
Yes Iberic area is including both Spain and Portugal, both EU member states.

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: Complete the sentence below with the appropriate option from the drop-down list.
This is a Blank Question. Within a sentence, one or more blank space(s) have to be filled with from a list of options (drop-down list).
EChemTest stands for
European
Electronic
Extended
Evaluation
Chemistry Test.
Correct, it is European Chemistry Test.
Wrong, this is European Chemistry Test, and not Electronic, Extended or Evaluation Chemistry Test.

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: Answer by "True" or "False" the following statements.

This is a "True/False" question. Like the Matching and Ranking questions, move the cursor onto the pop-up menu, select your answer by clicking on it. Repeat this procedure for each of the pop-up menus. If you want to change your mind, redo it for the one you want to change.

Centuries ago, salt was an exchange currency or trading market in desertical area (Africa, South-America, ...), and in some countries and for years, a tax system was in use all over Europe and built on salt.
True
False
Gold metal was always used as a trading / exchange system since the ancient Egypt and on all continents.
True
False
Iron is known since the ancient time, and was discovered at the so called "Iron age" (approximately at the 11-12th century A.C.).
True
False

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: <FONT COLOR=BLUE>Answer by "True" or "False" the following statements.</FONT><BR \><BR \>

This is a "True/False" question. Like the Matching and Ranking questions, move the cursor onto the pop-up menu, select your answer by clicking on it. Repeat this procedure for each of the pop-up menus. If you want to change mind, redo it for the one you want to change.
* Norwegian is one of the official European languages.
True
False
* The European flag contains the same number of stars as official languages.
True
False
* Irish is one exception. It is not considered as an official language (English is the official one) although it is spoken all over Ireland.
True
False
EU or EEC have only 11 official languages (Danish, Dutch, English, Finnish, French, German, Greek, Italian, Spanish, Portuguese, Swedish)

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext: There is 2 different spellings for the "S" element ...
This is a Text Match question, you are expected to type in the blank box, the word or sentence. Sometimes, it can be case sensitive.
Yes correct, the alternate spelling way is "Sulphur / sulphur".
Yes correct, the alternate spelling way is "Sulfur / sulfur".
Sorry the question was how to spell the element "S", either "Sulfur" or "Sulphur".

itemmetadata.qmd_topic: DDB English version\Tutorial on using the system

material.mattext:
The Training Test is now completed.
Was this test useful for you ? we hope so.
Click on "Proceed" to first review your answers and the question feedbacks of the Training test, then "Home" to access the Selection Window and start another Assessment if available with your account.
